author: By George Gurley
title: Bebe Buell, Rock ’n’ Roll Muse, Sings Her Own Song
description: Decades after those wild nights at Max’s Kansas City and her many rock-star romances, she is making the case for herself.
content: Bebe Buell was back in town.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: Why Trump Won’t Let Go of His Dream of Domination
description: It’s gotten him this far.
content: Throughout his life — in his overlapping business, TV and political careers — Donald Trump has attempted to portray himself as what is conventionally known as an alpha male. But now he has run into a buzz saw of criminal investigations and civil suits that threaten to reveal both the ludicrousness of his self-image and his failure to meet the traditional standards of leadership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman and Hiroko Masuike
title: They’ve Spent Years on the Streets. Can Anyone Coax Them Inside?
description: Half a year with the street counselors who dispense free sneakers, monthly injections and gentle encouragement to some of the city’s most vulnerable and volatile residents.
content: Chris Payton and Sonia Daley emerged from the subway into the brilliant sunshine to meet a client nesting on a pile of blankets near the Staten Island Ferry terminal in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: If You Stop Mowing This May, Will Your Lawn Turn Into a Meadow?
description: Not necessarily. Two new books offer some advice on what to expect when you decide to leave your lawn behind.
content: It’s No Mow May, time for the annual campaign that advocates just what it says: Skip mowing the lawn this month, in the name of providing additional resources for early-season pollinators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Want to Play Messi’s Argentina? Prepare to Pay Up.
description: Five months ago, Argentina won the biggest prize in soccer. Now teams across the world are fighting for the second biggest: the chance to play it.
content: All told, there were around a dozen offers for officials at Argentina’s national soccer federation to contemplate. They came, largely, from the game’s commercially lucrative emerging markets: the United States, China, Australia, Indonesia, the United Arab Emirates. The only outlier, really, was an unlikely bid from Bangladesh.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosie Gray
title: How Trump Cast the Republican Hawks Out Into the Cold
description: Over the past decade, he and Tucker Carlson have completely changed the way G.O.P. foreign policy politics work. What happens now?
content: Of the many Republican shibboleths Donald Trump blew up, the party’s foreign policy apparatus is among the most significant. Mr. Trump broke with decades of post-Reagan G.O.P. consensus that America should have a hegemonic presence in world affairs. But it’s not just the content. The way that he did it — often slapdash, based on gut feeling or on the advice of the inexperienced outsiders with whom he surrounded himself — was just as important as the shift.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert F. Worth
title: The President, the Soccer Hooligans and an Underworld ‘House of Horrors’
description: A grisly trial in Serbia has raised questions about connections between the country’s top leadership and its violent drug gangs.
content: On a Saturday night in early March 2021, Serbia’s president, Aleksandar Vucic, appeared on live television, seated at a long wooden table and flanked by the country’s prime minister and interior minister. Vucic said he had an important announcement to make about the arrest of an underworld gang responsible for multiple murders. The interior minister warned viewers to move their children away from the TV. A series of images flashed on the screen behind him: a severed head, a headless body, a torso. Vucic spoke slowly, often pausing and staring ponderously at the table in front of him, his 6-foot-6-inch frame hunched slightly. He praised the police and intelligence agents who investigated the gang; they had narrowly escaped being killed themselves, he said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 3, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, May 3, 2023.
content: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about how conflict in Sudan has reignited decades-long violence in Darfur misstated the United Nations office that Jérôme Merlin works for. It is the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, the body’s refugee agency, not the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Respect and Disdain: How Britain’s Generations Diverge on the Monarchy
description: The divide in Bristol goes a long way toward explaining the substantial split in public opinion about the role the royals play in a modern Britain.
content: A mural depicting Queen Elizabeth II in a yoga pose, with the message “Welcome to Bristol,” greets visitors to this vibrant city in southwestern England.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith, Martha Schwendener, John Vincler, Travis Diehl and Arthur Lubow
title: What to See in N.Y.C. Galleries in May
description: Want to see new art in the city? Check out Michael McGrath’s emoji landscapes, Enrique Chagoya’s “reverse anthropology” or King Cobra’s metaphorical butchery.
content: Peter Shear’s little paintings resemble terse, challenging poems. Painting and title resonate in the mind and eye. You decide whether these ricochets hold your interest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Haley Willis and Riley Mellen
title: Verified videos show two explosions over the Kremlin.
description: The explosions were separated by about 15 minutes and one caused a brief fire.
content: Video footage verified by The Times shows what appear to be two drones exploding minutes apart above the Kremlin early Wednesday, in what Russian officials claim was a Ukrainian attack, which Ukraine denies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: Tucker Carlson’s Code of Whiteness
description: The racial ideology revealed in the former Fox News host’s text message.
content: Gertrude Stein warned that remarks are not literature. Neither are hateful messages sent to a television producer’s smartphone and hidden away in redacted legal documents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Figure of Interest
description: Samuel A. Donaldson is back at it.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Eli Lilly Trial Finds Alzheimer’s Drug Can Slow Progress of Disease
description: Donanemab is not a cure and comes with significant side effects, but patients had longer periods of independent living while on the drug.
content: The drug manufacturer Eli Lilly announced on Wednesday that a clinical trial of an experimental Alzheimer’s drug showed it can slow progress of the feared disease and allow patients to have more time when they can still live independently, performing tasks like cooking meals, going to the store and driving a car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Coral Davenport
title: United Auto Workers Hold Off on Backing Biden, for Now
description: A memo by the union’s president underscores how some of President Biden’s moves to fight climate change could weaken some of his political support.
content: The United Auto Workers, a politically potent labor union, is planning to withhold its endorsement of President Biden in the early stages of the 2024 race, according to an internal memo from its president to members on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holly Peterson
title: Polo and Ponies: ‘My Money Pit of Choice’
description: The very wealthy recently gathered in South Florida for a weekend dedicated to the sport of kings.
content: MIAMI — Tito Gauenzi waved his arm across a party tent tricked out like an oceanfront nightclub. “Miami and polo don’t get any sexier than this,” said Mr. Gauenzi, the chief executive and founder of the Beach Polo World Cup in Miami.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elena Shao
title: ‘A New Spike’ in Global Temperatures in the Forecast
description: The World Meteorological Organization reports increased odds that El Niño, the global weather pattern often tied to intense heat, will arrive by fall.
content: Forecasters from the World Meteorological Organization are reporting increased chances that the global climate pattern known as El Niño will arrive by the end of summer. With it comes increased chances for hotter-than-normal temperatures in 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: In the Laker Big Man Tradition, Anthony Davis Sparkles in Game 1
description: Only Elgin Baylor, Wilt Chamberlain, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Shaquille O’Neal previously had 30 points and 20 rebounds in a Lakers playoff game.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Anthony Davis sat next to LeBron James, watching as James heaped praise upon him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Danish Wind Pioneer Keeps Battling Climate Change
description: Henrik Stiesdal helped design the first modern wind turbines. A thousand patents later, he’s a green tech entrepreneur rolling out new innovations.
content: The contemporary wind power industry, which has spawned hundreds of thousands of spinning rotors generating electricity without putting greenhouse gases into the air, was to a great extent born in a notoriously windy region of Denmark called Jutland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Brad Plumer
title: Companies Flock to Biden’s Climate Tax Breaks, Driving Up Cost
description: A law to boost clean energy appears to be more potent than predicted, with big implications for both budget talks and efforts to fight climate change.
content: President Biden’s signature climate law appears to be encouraging more investment in American manufacturing than initially expected, powering what’s expected to be a surge in new factory jobs and domestic clean energy technologies, according to independent forecasters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: New York City Will Finally Turn a Hotel Into Housing
description: Developers announced a plan to transform a Hilton hotel near Kennedy International Airport into affordable housing — the first conversion to take place through a pandemic-era state program.
content: The halting effort to transform struggling New York City hotels into much-needed affordable housing appears to be moving forward, at long last: An airport hotel in Queens is set to be turned into a housing development with more than 300 units.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Secret ‘Mission’ for Peace in Ukraine May Show Limits of Pope’s Influence
description: Since Francis made cryptic reference to a Vatican peace effort, the suggestion has elicited denial or bewilderment by war’s protagonists.
content: ROME — A secret mission revealed days ago by Pope Francis to bring peace between Russia and Ukraine is so secret that Russia and Ukraine claim to know nothing about it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: What to Watch at the Fed’s May Meeting
description: Federal Reserve officials will release a rate decision at 2 p.m. The key question is what will come next.
content: Follow live updates as Federal Reserve officials release a rate decision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete McKenzie
title: $59 Million, Gone: How Bikini Atoll Leaders Blew Through U.S. Trust Fund
description: The Trump administration lifted spending limits on the fund, which aids descendants of people forced to leave the coral reef because of U.S. nuclear testing.
content: The golden sand of Bikini Atoll is laced with plutonium. The freshwater is poisoned with strontium. The coconut crabs contain hazardous levels of cesium.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Can You Pass an 8th-Grade History Test?
description: Here are five questions of medium difficulty from the eighth-grade U.S. history test given by the federal government.
content: National test results on Wednesday showed a startling decline in eighth grade U.S. history scores, a trend that began nearly a decade ago and was accelerated by the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu, Benjamin Weiser and Kate Christobek
title: Trump Will Offer No Defense Witnesses in Rape Trial, His Lawyer Says
description: The lawyer said he would call no witnesses to rebut E. Jean Carroll’s account of being assaulted at Bergdorf Goodman. The case could go to a jury early next week.
content: A lawyer defending former President Donald J. Trump against the writer E. Jean Carroll’s lawsuit accusing him of rape said that he would present no witnesses during the trial, which completed its sixth day Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: When the Circus Came to a Ghost Town
description: Nipton, Calif., has one main road and about two dozen residents. Entrepreneurs with dreams of turning it around have come and gone. Will this time be different?
content: Since the days of the gold rush, dreamers hoping to strike it rich have been staking their claim to a dusty 80-acre town in the Mojave Desert called Nipton. For nearly all of them, those dreams have been fool’s gold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Catherine Pearson
title: A New Breast Pumping Law Has Gone Into Effect. Here’s What It Means.
description: Enhanced regulations aim to protect a greater number of working parents.
content: Last week, expanded protections for nursing mothers, officially known as the Providing Urgent Maternal Protections for Nursing Mothers Act, or PUMP Act, went into full effect, giving more workers the right to break time and a private space to pump. Congress passed the new legislation in December with large bipartisan support, but it was rolled out in phases to give employers time to adjust to the new requirements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: New Voter ID Rules Are Raising Hackles in Britain
description: Critics say the Conservative government’s new requirements are meant to discourage voting by young people and members of minority groups, who are likely to be Labour voters.
content: The rituals around voting have changed little for decades in Britain, where electors give their names and addresses to polling station staff, are checked off a list and then handed a paper ballot to mark and cast in a box.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Newly Published, From Roller Disco to ‘Frankenstein’ With Dinosaurs
description: A selection of recently published books.
content: THE LANGUAGE OF TREES: A Rewilding of Literature and Landscape, by Katie Holten. (Tin House, $29.95.) Over 50 writings from notable authors, philosophers, scientists and artists — including Plato, Ursula K. Le Guin and Ada Limón — are delicately translated into Holten’s visual “tree alphabet” in this ode to the world’s trees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Nothing Says Fashion in 2023 Like a Corset Hoodie
description: ‘A very weird hybrid’ of comfort and constriction has developed a cultlike following.
content: There is a certain futility in making sense of fashion trends of late. Just try to follow the path from naked dressing to stealth wealth without taking the pink-drenched detours of cottagecore, balletcore and Barbiecore. They all have a tendency to contradict one another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Zelensky arrives in the Netherlands for an address at The Hague, Dutch media reports.
description: The Ukrainian president has long urged that Vladimir Putin and others be held to account under international law.
content: AMSTERDAM — President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine unexpectedly traveled to the Netherlands on Wednesday and was scheduled to speak in The Hague on Thursday, according to the Dutch wire service ANP.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Kate Bush, Missy Elliott and Willie Nelson Voted Into Rock Hall of Fame
description: Rounding out the far-from-traditional class of 2023: George Michael, Sheryl Crow, Rage Against the Machine and the Spinners.
content: The reclusive (but freshly relevant) experimental pop singer Kate Bush, the one-of-one rapper Missy Elliott and the 90-year-old country stalwart Willie Nelson are among this year’s genre-spanning inductees to the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame. The organization behind the museum and annual ceremony announced the lineup on Wednesday, underlining how the new class reflected “the diverse artists and sounds that define rock & roll.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: A Bright Coronation Chicken Salad and a No-Slump Quiche Crust
description: A British classic is perked up with yogurt and curry paste, and a simple trick that will help your quiche crusts stand taller.
content: This Saturday King Charles III and Queen Camilla will be crowned in London, which is the best excuse in my lifetime so far to whip up a festive British-inspired coronation feast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: What Are the Best Places to Eat in Your Town?
description: How often do you dine out? Whether you like famous restaurants, local diners or food carts, what are your favorite places to eat? Why?
content: How often do you eat out? Where do you like to go most? What are your favorite dishes?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Thursday Briefing: Explosions over the Kremlin
description: Also, American miscalculations in Sudan.
content: Two explosions occurred 15 minutes apart over the Kremlin early yesterday, video footage verified by The Times showed. The incident set off a flurry of accusations and escalated tensions between Russia and Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: The Debt Limit Standoff is a New Economic Headwind for the Fed
description: The central bank must consider how looming U.S. default could impact the economy as it makes a decision on raising interest rates.
content: The Federal Reserve’s decision about whether to continue raising interest rates comes at a fraught economic moment for the United States, with President Biden and Republicans in Congress locked in a standoff over how to raise the nation’s debt limit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Treffinger
title: Design Advice for a Less Toxic Life
description: Advice on healthy candles, purging kitchen plastic and the art of dyeing fabric naturally.
content: I’ve heard some candles can create indoor air pollution and even be harmful. Are there safer alternatives?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: How Did the Devils Get So Fast, So Fast?
description: The Devils, who had gone a decade without winning a playoff series until Monday, beat the Rangers with speed and a sensational rookie goalie. Now they’re about to face a hurricane.
content: Jack Hughes thought he had it pretty good as a professional hockey player. The No. 1 draft pick in 2019, Hughes was living his best life over the ensuing four seasons, skating for the Devils and emerging as a superstar in the N.H.L.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen and Liz Alderman
title: The ‘Peace Dividend’ Is Over in Europe. Now Come the Hard Tradeoffs.
description: Defending against an unpredictable Russia in years to come will mean bumping up against a strained social safety net and ambitious climate transition plans.
content: In the 30 years since the Iron Curtain came crashing down, trillions of dollars that had been dedicated to Cold War armies and weapons systems were gradually diverted to health care, housing and schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: The Fed Opens the Door to a Rate Pause
description: Also, Russia accuses Ukraine of launching drones at the Kremlin and an indie film nabs a star voice. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: The Federal Reserve continued its aggressive campaign to rein in inflation by slowing the economy, lifting interest rates by a quarter-point. But there was also a notable shift in the central bank’s stance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Feathers in a Coronation Cap
description: Amid the crowns, fascinators and tiaras at the crowning of King Charles III, a plume of humble swan feathers takes its place.
content: Reporting here from the Department of Great State Occasions, Minutiae Division. Subject: swan plumes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3’ Review: Raccoon Tears and a Final Mixtape
description: This dour, visually off-putting two-and-a-half-hour A.S.P.C.A. nightmare of a film may only be for completionist fans.
content: Animal lovers, comic book fans and unofficial adjudicators of narrative continuity, action and style in the Marvel Cinematic Universe: Lend me your ears. “Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3” is not the movie for you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Chris Christie Taunts Trump as ‘Afraid’ of Presidential Debates
description: Mr. Christie, who is weighing a presidential bid, also called Donald Trump “a child” for fixating on the 2020 election and said “he doesn’t have a lot of serious answers” for the nation’s problems.
content: Former Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, one of the few potential Republican presidential candidates willing to attack Donald J. Trump directly, laced into the former president on Wednesday over his reported reluctance to participate in presidential debates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Tori Bowie, World Champion Sprinter, Is Dead at 32
description: She won three Olympic medals in 2016 and the world championship the next year in an intense 100-meter dash.
content: Tori Bowie, a sprinter who won three medals at the 2016 Olympics in Rio de Janeiro and the next year won the world championship in the 100-meter dash with a stunning comeback, has died. She was 32.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Travis Diehl
title: Mimicking the 19th Century in the Age of A.I.
description: Many artists are using the latest A.I.-powered digital techniques to create a nostalgic past — an ironic throwback. Seth Price manages to be contemporary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Congress Clashes With Biden Over Tariffs on Illegal Chinese Solar Panels
description: In a rebuke to the Biden administration, the Senate approved a measure to reinstate tariffs on solar panels found to violate U.S. trade rules.
content: The Senate voted on Wednesday to reinstate tariffs on solar panels from Chinese companies in Southeast Asia that had been found to be coming into the United States in violation of trade rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: A South Korean Horror Story, Long Suppressed
description: The story of a brutal sex trade built for American soldiers shows how women have been exploited in service of political and economic goals.
content: It’s only Wednesday, but for my money, the most important international article The New York Times will publish this week is this one about women in South Korea forced or tricked into violent sexual servitude as “comfort women” for foreign soldiers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Billionaire Investor Buys Epstein’s Private Islands for $60 Million
description: Stephen Deckoff, the founder of Black Diamond Capital Management, said he planned to build a 25-room resort on the islands once owned by the disgraced financier and registered sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.
content: A billionaire investor with ties to the U.S. Virgin Islands paid $60 million to buy Jeffrey Epstein’s island residences off the coast of St. Thomas — closing another chapter in the financial dealings of the disgraced financier who died by suicide in 2019 in a Manhattan jail while awaiting trial on sex-trafficking charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Carlos Prieto, Sydney Harper, Rikki Novetsky, Michael Simon Johnson, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Patricia Willens, Rachel Quester, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
title: The Democrats’ Dianne Feinstein Problem
description: The senator’s absence is at the center of a growing political crisis.
content: For the past few months, a single lawmaker has prevented Democrats from carrying out their agenda in Congress. For now, there is no simple solution in sight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein and Sadiba Hasan
title: The Met Gala Was Just the Start. Welcome to the After-Parties.
description: Sean Combs, Dua Lipa, Lizzo and Janelle Monáe were among the revelers who kept going after the formal affair, with drinks, dancing and no cockroach sightings.
content: At 11 p.m., outside the Mark Hotel on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, gawkers pressed up against police barricades, hoping to catch a glimpse of someone — anyone — who had been at the Met Gala and was now showing up to the first of its after-parties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean Keenan, Eduardo Medina, Remy Tumin and Johnny Diaz
title: Suspect Caught After Killing 1 and Injuring 4 in Atlanta Shooting, Police Say
description: The authorities said that the 24-year-old suspect in the attack at an Atlanta medical building had been caught after an extensive manhunt that lasted several hours.
content: ATLANTA — A gunman who opened fire at a medical office building in Midtown Atlanta on Wednesday, killing one and injuring four others, has been caught after a manhunt that lasted several hours, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Vermont Removes Residency Requirement for Medically Assisted Deaths
description: The change, signed into law by the state’s governor, followed a legal challenge brought by a 75-year-old Connecticut resident.
content: Vermont has become the first state to remove a residency requirement from its law on medically assisted death to allow terminally ill people from out of state access to life-ending care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Nereim
title: Fleeing Sudan, Some Find Saudi Ships ‘a Golden Opportunity’ to Escape
description: A Sudanese student waiting to be evacuated by Saudi Arabia counted himself as one of the lucky ones: Born in the kingdom and holding a residency permit, he could board a rescue ship.
content: A few weeks ago, Ahmed al-Hassan was a medical student in Sudan working on a campaign to help refugees from a neighboring country. Then, the forces of two rival generals went to battle in the streets of the capital, Khartoum, and he was forced to flee himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins
title: Repulsed by Biden vs. Trump? Tough.
description: Third parties aren’t going to save us.
content: The presidential race sure does seem like it’ll wind up coming down to Biden vs. Trump — and a whole lot of people would rather have an alternative.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Ajay Banga Confirmed as World Bank Leader
description: Mr. Banga’s appointment to a five-year term was confirmed on Wednesday by the World Bank.
content: Ajay Banga, President Biden’s pick to be president of the World Bank and broaden its ambitions to combat climate change, was approved by its executive board on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aamina Inayat Khan
title: A Pakistani Artist Reimagines Her Relationship With Shame and Bodies
description: With body castings of anonymized Pakistani women that resemble oxidized copper statues, Misha Japanwala hopes to create a time capsule of resisting gender violence for her new gallery show.
content: Misha Japanwala looked around her studio in the week leading up to her gallery show and wondered whether there were “too many nipples.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: Jack Dorsey Has a Lot to Say, Including About Elon Musk and Twitter
description: The Twitter co-founder has posted prolifically on two new social networks, Nostr and Bluesky, which he also backed financially.
content: Jack Dorsey has barely posted on Twitter, the social media platform he helped create, since January. In two of his last tweets, the billionaire entrepreneur promoted an app for Nostr, a new social network.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Will Poulter Is Just Getting Used to His Superhero Era
description: The once-gawky British actor buffed up to play Adam Warlock in “Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3.” But he says, in his head, he’s still 5-foot-4.
content: Even when people don’t know Will Poulter’s name, they recognize his face. It helps that the 30-year-old Brit has been acting for half his life and has racked up an eclectic list of film credits, though he’s also blessed with a pair of distinctive eyebrows that are as curvy and expressive as a fleur-de-lis. They pull people in, even if those people aren’t always sure where to place the on-the-cusp actor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith
title: Common Consumer Products Contain Multiple Toxic Chemicals, New Study Shows
description: Hair and nail products, all-purpose cleaners and automotive products contain some of the highest numbers of chemicals.
content: More than 100 types of common consumer products contain at least one, and often multiple, chemicals linked to cancer or reproductive and developmental problems, according to research published Tuesday in the journal Environmental Science & Technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johanna Lemola
title: Zelensky says Russia is trying to stoke support at home by blaming Kyiv.
description: The Ukrainian president flatly denied that his country was behind any drone attack on the Kremlin.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine denied on Wednesday that his country was responsible for an early morning drone attack on the Kremlin, saying that Russia was blaming Ukraine because it had lost other means of mustering domestic  support for its invasion of his country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Pamela Timmins, Press Secretary to Jacqueline Kennedy, Dies at 85
description: She was the first person to hold the post for an American first lady, helping Mrs. Kennedy navigate times both dazzling and tragic.
content: The president was concerned about what a windblown ride in a motorcade would do to his wife’s hair. He asked her press secretary, Pamela Turnure Timmins, for advice. She proposed that the couple not ride in a convertible.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Push to Reverse ‘Wokeness’ at U.Va.
description: Reaction to a campaign led by a University of Virginia board member against D.E.I. programs. Also: The National Academy of Sciences, on the Sackler donations.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Grace Ashford
title: How New Yorkers’ Lives Will Be Altered by the $229 Billion State Budget
description: The budget contains a handful of contentious policy changes on issues like bail, minimum wage and a ban on gas stoves and furnaces in new construction.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — Minimum wage workers in New York City will get a pay bump for the first time in five years. Out-of-state students at city and state universities will face a tuition hike. And cigarette smokers will need to pay an extra dollar in taxes per pack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: My Weekend With an Emotional Support A.I. Companion
description: Pi, an A.I. tool that debuted this week, is a twist on the new wave of chatbots: It assists people with their wellness and emotions.
content: For several hours on Friday evening, I ignored my husband and dog and allowed a chatbot named Pi to validate the heck out of me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: Tracing the Angry Path From Timothy McVeigh to Trumpism
description: “Homegrown,” by Jeffrey Toobin, revisits the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing, finding ominous parallels between the bomber’s anti-government extremism and the views of Jan. 6 insurrectionists.
content: It was the dog whistle heard ’round the world. When Donald J. Trump decided to kick off his latest presidential campaign on March 25 with a rally at Waco, Texas, he was issuing a call to the far-right fringe that was earsplitting, even by his own standards. It wasn’t simply the location but also the timing: a month shy of the 30th anniversary of April 19, 1993 — a date that marked the fiery, deadly end of the 51-day standoff between the F.B.I. and David Koresh at his Branch Davidian compound near Waco.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: ‘Bone Valley’ Podcast Subject Denied Parole Again in Wife’s Murder
description: Leo Schofield will be transferred to a prison with a transitional program. He has maintained innocence in his wife’s murder in 1987, and another man has since confessed to the killing.
content: For 34 years, Leo Schofield Jr. has been imprisoned in Florida for the murder of his wife, Michelle Schofield. He has maintained his innocence and has been denied parole three times, even after another man convicted of murder in a separate case admitted to the killing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Debt Ceiling and False Equivalence
description: The outcome of the debt ceiling conflict is genuinely uncertain.
content: The hardest political stories for reporters to cover and pundits to analyze can be those that are neither 100 percent stories nor 50 percent stories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Haley Willis
title: Moscow Claims Explosions Above the Kremlin Were an Attempt to Kill Putin
description: Russia said Ukraine had launched a drone attack, which Kyiv vehemently denied, accusing Russia of manufacturing a pretext for escalation.
content: After a pair of explosions above the Kremlin early Wednesday, Russia accused Ukraine of trying to assassinate President Vladimir V. Putin with a drone attack, but Kyiv denied any involvement in an incident that could raise the already-high stakes in Europe’s biggest conflict since World War II.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Makes 10th Rate Increase and Opens Door to Pause
description: The Fed raised rates by a quarter point, bringing them above 5 percent for the first time in more than 15 years.
content: Federal Reserve officials raised interest rates by a quarter-point on Wednesday, the 10th straight increase in an aggressive campaign to tame rapid inflation. But they also opened the door to pausing rate increases as their policies combine with bank turmoil to weigh down the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and Daniel Victor
title: Blinken says the U.S. is ‘intensely engaged’ in efforts to free Evan Gershkovich.
description: The Wall Street Journal reporter has been held for more than a month on espionage charges that the United States considers bogus.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said on Wednesday that the U.S. government remained “intensely engaged” in efforts to get Moscow to free Evan Gershkovich, the Wall Street Journal reporter who has been held for more than a month on espionage charges that his employer and American officials vehemently deny.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Met Gala Looks
description: What were your favorite and least favorite costumes at this year’s show?
content: On Monday, celebrities walked the red carpet for the annual benefit for the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Costume Institute, known as the Met Gala.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Orr
title: ‘Ted Lasso,’ Season 3, Episode 8 Recap: Ends and Beginnings
description: Ted prepares for a new reality, Nate plunges in and Keeley (maybe) steps away.
content: This is yet another episode that feels somewhat disjointed, following multiple story lines that don’t overlap much or offer a strong through-line. One could make the case — as I did in the headline — that this is an episode about the ends and beginnings of relationships. But the subplots nonetheless felt more like separate pieces than parts of a whole.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Dead Father Had a Secret. Do I Tell Our Family?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether to share a surprising discovery.
content: My father passed away two years ago at age 86. He served in the military for six years in the 1950s and was buried with full military honors. Although my father occasionally told stories about his time in service, he never went into great detail about it, and he kept no documents from that time. It wasn’t until about 25 years ago that my siblings and I learned my father had a child, later given up for adoption, while stationed in England. This was before he married my mother, and this knowledge came to the surface only when my half sister reached out to find her birth parents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: A.I. Could Actually Be a Boon to Education
description: The founder of Khan Academy believes that A.I. can change the teaching game for good.
content: Sal Khan is an uber-nerd, and that’s why people love him. In early 2020, to demonstrate that Khan Academy, his platform for free online education, was a worthy cause, he didn’t produce a brochure with smiling children and glowing testimonials. He made one of his teaching videos, with the usual black screen, colored pens and handwritten equations. The phrase “standard deviation” came up a lot. He multiplied the number of highly active users of his program by their average academic improvement, then linked that to the resulting increase in their projected lifetime earnings, compared it to operating costs and, presto, showed a benefit-cost ratio of 480 to 1, or around 240 to 1 if calculating only the benefits to students in high-need schools.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tucker Carlson’s Text, and ‘an Internal Struggle With Morality’
description: Readers write that the text that contributed to his firing also showed a recognition of our common humanity.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Russian pressure on civilians in occupied Ukraine.
content: The Russian authorities in occupied territory of Ukraine have imposed strict new measures on civilians. Most recently, they have “reinforced” counterintelligence units and are restricting travel between towns and villages, Ukraine’s military high command said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: I Knew My Father Cheated. Is My Parents’ Divorce My Fault?
description: After witnessing her father at a motel with a woman who was not her mother, a young reader describes experiencing near-daily guilt about not having spoken up.
content: Three years ago, when I was 15, I saw my dad going into a motel with a woman I didn’t know. I happened to be getting frozen yogurt with friends next door. I was totally freaked out, but I said nothing. I just pretended it never happened. A few months later, my mom asked me directly if I thought my dad was having an affair. I said I didn’t — which was obviously a lie. My parents separated, then divorced, about a year later. Pretty much every day since then, I have felt guilty about my behavior. Do you think if I’d confronted my dad or told my mom the truth, at the time, my parents might still be married today?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson and Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Guard Who Fatally Shot Man at a Walgreens Won’t Be Charged, Prosecutor Says
description: The San Francisco district attorney, Brooke Jenkins, said the security guard “believed he was in mortal danger and acted in self-defense.”
content: A security guard at a Walgreens in San Francisco will not be charged with murder after he fatally shot a man who was accused of shoplifting, the district attorney said this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced and Lauren Hirsch
title: Markets Expect the Fed to Raise Rates Despite Banking Turmoil
description: A ‘shock pause’ by the central bank would spook an already jittery market, one analyst said, even as shares in regional lenders fall.
content: If market predictions are correct, the Fed on Wednesday will raise borrowing costs by a quarter of a percentage point, even as growing turmoil in the stocks of regional banks threatens to choke off credit to businesses and consumers, pushing the economy into recession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: temperamental
description: This word has appeared in 59 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word temperamental has appeared in 59 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 9 in the Opinion essay “How Do You Serve a Friend in Despair?” by David Brooks:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh
title: It’s Not Just Math and Reading: U.S. History Scores for 8th Graders Plunge
description: The latest test results continue a nearly decade-long decline. Try a sample quiz to test your knowledge.
content: National test scores released on Wednesday showed a marked drop in students’ knowledge of U.S. history and a modest decline in civics, a sign of the pandemic’s alarming reach, damaging student performance in nearly every academic area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Rose Woods
title: A Crown, an Orb and a 12th-Century Spoon
description: When it comes to some national spectacles, anachronism is a feature, not a bug.
content: On Saturday morning, Charles Philip Arthur George Mountbatten-Windsor will leave Buckingham Palace in a carriage drawn by six horses, take a slightly circuitous route through central London and arrive at Westminster Abbey, a little before 11 a.m., for a ceremony mostly unchanged over the course of a millennium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: At Trisha Brown, a New Voice With a Family Resemblance
description: A premiere by Judith Sánchez Ruíz goes its own way but, like Brown’s work, shows an active, questioning mind and a sensual physicality.
content: When the choreographer Trisha Brown died in 2017, the life of the company that she had founded decades earlier was uncertain. Would her works, some of the finest in contemporary dance, survive? Would audiences still want to see them?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: John Mulaney and the Insatiable Modern Audience
description: Even when an artist works in an autobiographical mode, fans aren’t entitled to everything.
content: In John Mulaney’s new Netflix special, “Baby J,” the comedian tells a story about one of the “most desperate” things he did while addicted to cocaine: In early 2020, he really wanted to stop using. But instead of reaching out to a therapist or a friend, he called his accountant and told him, “The only way you can give me cash is if I email you and cc my doctor. That’s the new rule.” Mulaney then tells us how he spent the next several months trying to circumvent his own rule, including by buying a $12,000 Rolex on a credit card and then pawning it for $6,000 so he could buy drugs with the cash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: 5 Million New Yorkers Just Got Better Health Care
description: After a class-action suit, people on Medicaid will get coverage for dental care, including root canals and implants.
content: Good morning. There are people who actually want root canals. We’ll look at a change in state rules that means they can now get them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arlene Hirst
title: As Traditional Bulbs Fade Out, LED Lights Keep Improving
description: They last much longer, can be dimmed and now produce light in a variety of colors.
content: More than any other technology, LEDs, or light-emitting diodes, have transformed the universe of illumination. Tiny yet mighty, these energy-saving wonders have replaced the once-ubiquitous incandescent bulb, the majority of which will be banned by the Energy Department as of this summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johanna Lemola and Enjoli Liston
title: Zelensky Travels to Finland to Meet With Nordic Leaders
description: The Ukrainian president has made few overseas trips since Russia launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine.
content: HELSINKI — President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine arrived in Finland on Wednesday to meet with Nordic leaders, a rare overseas trip for the Ukrainian leader amid the Russian invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Ezersky
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: Carl Icahn, Activist Investor, Becomes Target of Short Seller
description: Hindenburg Research, which made its name by taking on Gautam Adani and the Twitter co-founder Jack Dorsey, likened Icahn Enterprises to “Ponzi-like economic structures.”
content: Over nearly a half-century, Carl Icahn has shaken up Wall Street as a corporate raider and activist shareholder, making corporate titans bow down to his demands and change their business strategies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Shaw
title: An Architect Known for Building Castles in the ‘Vegetable Kingdom’
description: A man of many hats, Emilio Ambasz practiced green architecture long before it was fashionable.
content: When the architect Emilio Ambasz won a 1998 competition to redesign the headquarters of Eni S.p.A., an oil company controlled by the Italian government, he recalled wagging a metaphorical finger at the company’s president, saying: “You owe it to Italy to do something green.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Jeffery C. Mays
title: Hochul’s Ex-Adviser Has History of Sexual Harassment Complaints
description: Nearly six years before Adam Sullivan lost his job with Gov. Kathy Hochul, a Democratic group fired him amid sexual harassment complaints from colleagues.
content: Sarah Driscoll was out for drinks with colleagues one evening in early 2017 when a veteran political operative she worked with, Adam C. Sullivan, cornered her at a Washington bar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: We’re Watching the End of a Digital Media Age. It All Started With Jezebel.
description: The feminist site Jezebel presaged major changes in the way America talks about race and gender and pioneered the fusion of audience, writers, politics and identity.
content: Ten years ago, a group of digital media companies thought the future belonged to us. New brands like Vice, Gawker, The Huffington Post, Business Insider and BuzzFeed News, which I helped start, had begun as blogs or something similar, outsider voices with audiences who were sick of the stuffy mainstream media. They’d grown steadily on the internet, and when Facebook arrived, they exploded with the social platform. They became expert in telling stories in a way people would like and share, and their links became omnipresent in readers’ newsfeeds. Their voices dominated the influential, sometimes toxic conversations on Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: For King Charles, Coronation Day Is a Step on a Tightrope Walk
description: Britain’s head of state is said to want a more accessible, forward-looking and inclusive monarchy. It’s not an easy message to convey through golden relics and ancient rituals.
content: It’s good to be the king. But it’s not without its traps, as King Charles III learned last weekend when the organizers of his coronation invited millions of Britons to pledge an oath of homage to the monarch during the ceremony on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Morales
title: The Bassist Carlos Henriquez Covers All the Latin and Jazz Bases
description: The longtime Jazz at Lincoln Center musician leads a tribute this weekend to his mambo ancestors Tito Puente and Tito Rodríguez.
content: As he worked his way through a rice bowl at a Japanese restaurant near Columbus Circle in Manhattan on a recent afternoon, the bassist, composer and arranger Carlos Henriquez reflected on the long history of Latino musicians in the jazz world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht
title: 7th Grader Opens Fire at School in Serbia, Killing 8 Children
description: The assailant had two pistols, four Molotov cocktails and detailed plans, the police said. A security guard was also killed.
content: A seventh-grade student armed with pistols and Molotov cocktails ​shot and killed eight children and a security guard on Wednesday in an attack against his school in the Serbian capital, Belgrade, shock​ing a country where gun ownership is high but violence from the weapons is rare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer
title: F.T.C. Seeks ‘Blanket’ Ban on Meta’s Use of Young Users’ Data
description: Citing privacy failings by the tech giant, regulators proposed to stop sites like Instagram and Facebook from profiting off the data of users under 18.
content: The Federal Trade Commission escalated its fight with the tech industry’s biggest companies on Wednesday as it moved to impose what it called a “blanket prohibition” on the collection of young people’s personal data by Meta, Facebook’s parent company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling
title: Outside Hollywood Studios, Writers Make Their Case
description: Those in picket lines at the headquarters of companies like Netflix were critical of working conditions that have become routine in the streaming era.
content: Ellen Stutzman, a senior Writers Guild of America official, stood on a battered patch of grass outside Netflix headquarters in Los Angeles. She was calm — remarkably so, given the wild scene unfolding around her, and the role she had played in its creation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Rep. Colin Allred of Texas Will Challenge Ted Cruz for Senate
description: Mr. Allred, a Democrat and former N.F.L. linebacker, said he would try to unseat Mr. Cruz, who held off Beto O’Rourke in 2018.
content: HOUSTON — Representative Colin Allred, a Dallas-area Democrat who defeated an incumbent Republican to gain his seat in 2018, announced on Wednesday that he would challenge Senator Ted Cruz of Texas next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters, Michael S. Schmidt and Jim Rutenberg
title: Carlson’s Text That Alarmed Fox Leaders: ‘It’s Not How White Men Fight’
description: The discovery of the text message contributed to a chain of events that ultimately led to Tucker Carlson’s firing.
content: A text message sent by Tucker Carlson that set off a panic at the highest levels of Fox on the eve of its billion-dollar defamation trial showed its most popular host sharing his private, inflammatory views about violence and race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Feldman
title: What’s Happening at New York’s Design Festival?
description: As New York City prepares to roll out its annual home design event starting in May, we share a plenitude of bright spots to look out for this year.
content: NYCxDesign, the citywide festival celebrating the beauty of homey objects — including furniture, fabric, lighting and tabletop accessories — returns for its 11th season on May 18-25. Scores of exhibitions, product launches and shopping experiences will carpet the city throughout that week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: Chris Wheeldon’s ‘Dangerous and Exciting’ Adventure at City Ballet
description: Wheeldon is back at New York City Ballet, where he honed his choreographic skills, making a non-narrative work set to Schoenberg.
content: “It’s not you, it’s me,” Christopher Wheeldon said, stopping the ballerina Sara Mearns, who was trying to work out a tricky movement phrase. She put her hands on her hips and laughed. “Don’t worry,” she said. “We’ve got three weeks. That’s like a year in New York City Ballet time.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Washington
title: The Particular Magic of Chicken, Egg and Rice
description: A straightforward Japanese rice bowl finds perfection in simplicity.
content: In virtually every circumstance that comes to mind, a steaming pile of rice is stellar on its own. But to top those grains with ingredients simmered in dashi and soy sauce, before they’re set into a bowl and sprinkled with scallions and shichimi, culminating in delicious donburi, is another plane of pleasure entirely. As straightforward as these Japanese rice bowls may seem — (perfect) rice! Covered with (perfectly) poached ingredients! Served in a (perfect) bowl! — their understatedness belie their exquisiteness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: Why Does Bad Science on Covid’s Origin Get Hyped?
description: If the raccoon dog was a smoking gun, it fired blanks.
content: You might think that, over the past year or two, public debate about the origins of the pandemic has loosened up. The lab-leak hypothesis has been aired repeatedly in Congress and endorsed with varying degrees of confidence by some intelligence agencies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dayna Evans
title: She Wants to Rewrite the Story of Art, Without Men
description: Hanging out at MoMa with Katy Hessel, a British art historian, podcast host and curator of the Great Women Artists Instagram account.
content: On a Wednesday in March at the Museum of Modern Art in New York City, the art historian, curator and podcaster Katy Hessel lingered by Leonora Carrington’s 1953 painting “And Then We Saw the Daughter of the Minotaur.” The mysterious dreamscape depicts a white bull in a red robe, seated at a table covered in crystal spheres. Two pale children dressed in black cloaks seem to be seeking guidance from the bull, as well as a phantom spirit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Meet the House Republicans Who Democrats Hope Will Defect on the Debt Limit
description: A long-shot Democratic effort to force a debt-limit increase to the floor hinges on at least five G.O.P. defections. These House Republicans are considered the likeliest.
content: WASHINGTON — House Democrats who this week began a long-shot bid attempting to force a debt limit increase bill to the floor are pinning their hopes not just on a convoluted legislative gambit, but also on another highly improbable feat: getting a small group of Republicans to cross party lines and join them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: The Population of California Declined, Again
description: In 2022, the state’s population dropped by roughly 138,400 people, to 38.94 million.
content: It was big news a few years ago when, for the first time in more than a century, California’s population shrank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: What Is the Kremlin, the Heart of Putin’s Security Bubble in Russia?
description: The Russian president resides at various heavily guarded locations and travels frequently between Moscow and a compound in an elite suburb miles away.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin has long operated within the confines of a tight security bubble, which became even tighter and more isolating during the coronavirus pandemic. The sprawling red fortress of the Kremlin, which Russian officials claimed was the target of a Ukrainian drone attack on Wednesday, contains both the president’s official residence and his main office, making it the heart of that bubble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Tucker Carlson, ‘White Men’ and the Lynch Mob Mentality
description: What the cable host could ‘taste’ in the heat of the moment was the power to assign death.
content: I have always been interested in the psychology of lynch mobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Margolies
title: Tiny Homes for the Formerly Homeless
description: A program that builds small energy-efficient houses in the backyards of Seattle residents is helping to address a persistent problem.
content: Twelve people who had been living on the streets of Seattle are now snug in 12 tiny houses tucked into backyards throughout Washington’s largest city. And each little dwelling is likely the most sustainable house on its block.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arafat Mugabo and Emma Bubola
title: Floods and Landslides Kill More Than 120 in Rwanda
description: Many areas across East Africa have in recent years experienced both severe droughts and heavy rainfalls that killed many and damaged property and crops.
content: More than 120 people were killed in devastating floods and landslides caused by heavy rains in Rwanda, the government said on Wednesday, the highest death toll from a flood reported in a single day in the country’s recent history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Bearak
title: Oil Executive Who Heads U.N. Climate Talks Hints at His Approach
description: In a speech, Sultan al-Jaber, the Emirati official presiding over this year’s climate summit, spoke of emissions cuts, but experts also cited ambiguity in his statements.
content: Scientists and activists have long argued at global climate summits that the only way to slow down global warming is to eliminate its main driver, fossil fuel production.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Flávia Milhorance and Ana Ionova
title: Brazil’s Police Raid Bolsonaro Home in Fake Vaccine Cards Case
description: The authorities arrested a close aide of former President Jair Bolsonaro on charges that he forged vaccine records, possibly to help Mr. Bolsonaro enter the United States.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — The Brazilian police raided the home of former President Jair Bolsonaro on Wednesday and seized his cellphone as part of a sweeping investigation into forged Covid-19 vaccination records that may have allowed him and his top aides to gain entry into the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Thomas
title: At 6 Catskills Resorts: Retro Design, Modern Comfort and Games, Lots of Games
description: Lodgings in this bucolic region north of New York City are targeting a new generation of visitors with organized “experiences,” nostalgic style elements and serious cocktails.
content: Picture yourself on a sojourn in the Catskill Mountains of New York. Would your preferred game be Pac-Man, pickleball or backgammon? The answer could determine where you stay. Then again, with the variety of games on hand at nearly every one of the Catskills’ newest wave of stylish resorts, there should be more than one option that tickles your fancy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: R.S.V. Vaccine Approved for Older Adults
description: The shots would be the first vaccines available against a respiratory virus that kills thousands and leads to many more hospitalizations each year.
content: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday approved GSK’s vaccine for the respiratory syncytial virus, or R.S.V., for adults who are 60 and older, the company said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcus J. Moore
title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Herbie Hancock
description: We asked musicians and experts, including Thundercat, Patrice Rushen and Nicole Sweeney, which Hancock song they would play for a friend.
content: Over the past few months, The New York Times has asked experts to answer the question, What would you play a friend to make them fall in love with jazz? We’ve explored artists like Ornette Coleman and Mary Lou Williams, and styles ranging from bebop to modern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Turn Your Pasta Primavera Into a Lasagna
description: Layered with asparagus, spinach, peas and lemony ricotta, this springy recipe from Melissa Clark is the cheesy dish for right now.
content: In the United States, lasagna almost universally entails tomato sauce, mozzarella and ricotta. However, a recent visit to Italy reminded me that the lasagna family is, in fact, vast and varied. There are hard-boiled egg and meatball-stuffed lasagnas from Naples; chicken liver studded ones from Le Marche; Bolognese and béchamel-swathed examples from Emilia-Romagna.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller
title: More U.S. Women Are Avoiding Unwanted or Mistimed Pregnancies
description: But a growing share of women over 35 say their pregnancies are coming later than they want, a new analysis found.
content: Births and pregnancies in the United States have been on a long-term decline. A new data analysis provides one reason: It’s becoming less common for women to get pregnant when they don’t want to be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Imani Danielle Mosley
title: Charles III’s Coronation: Music That Made Kings and Queens
description: How the sounds of this royal ceremony evolved, from the 10th century to Elizabeth II and her son’s coronation on Saturday.
content: The coronation ceremony of King Charles III and Camilla, the queen consort, on Saturday has been described as a millennium-old tradition of pomp and circumstance, reaching back to Charles’s most distant forebears.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ella Riley-Adams
title: The Painter Who Inspired a New Ballet
description: For Christopher Wheeldon’s return to New York City Ballet, he asked the artist Kylie Manning not just for backdrops and costumes but to, as he says, “form a dance within her world.”
content: In Kylie Manning’s paintings, figures swirl and emerge from broad landscapes. The wall-filling pieces can provoke a physical reaction, akin to looking over the rail of a bridge across a river. On a recent visit to the artist’s studio in Ridgewood, Queens, steadiness arrived in the form of tea and snacks: Manning, 39, wearing a paint-splattered green jumpsuit with black Crocs, had laid out dulce de leche fudge from the bodega down the street, along with chocolate she brought home from Geneva, where she’d just installed her latest solo show at Pace Gallery’s Swiss outpost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Curry
title: The Outrageous Star Power of El Duque
description: Orlando Hernández joined the Yankees rotation in June 1998 and proceeded to exceed all expectations. Then he saved the team’s season.
content: The mystery man was tall and lean and he was smiling, perpetually smiling. His life had dramatically changed when he left Cuba in a fishing boat, and it was about to change again. Every day featured more changes, more smiles and more glimpses of the pitcher known as El Duque.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Treffinger
title: Harnessing Earth and Fire to Create Natural Vessels
description: Mitch Iburg, a ceramic artist, goes to great lengths to ensure that his pieces are easier on the environment.
content: Mitch Iburg, who lives in St. Paul, Minn., makes ancient-looking tableware, vessels and sculptures primarily out of clay that he digs from the earth with his own hands (and some tools). Driving his truck two and half hours to an open valley near the Minnesota River, he comes away with 1,000 or so pounds — a quantity that will last him roughly a year. (He has permission from the mining company that owns the property.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing and Melissa Eddy
title: Former Audi Chief to Plead Guilty in Emissions Scandal
description: Rupert Stadler, a former member of Volkswagen’s management board, would be the highest-ranking executive to confess wrongdoing in a case that rocked the industry.
content: Rupert Stadler, the former chief executive of the automaker Volkswagen's Audi division, has agreed to plead guilty to charges in Germany related a vast emissions cheating scandal, becoming the highest-ranking executive to be convicted in the case, which changed the direction of the car industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Spread the Word: The Winners of Our 10th Annual 15-Second Vocabulary Video Challenge
description: Thank you to the more than 1,300 students who participated this year. Check out the winning videos to learn 11 new words.
content: Do you have three minutes to learn 11 new words?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Belarus Opposition Activist Whose Flight Was Forced Down Is Sentenced to 8 Years
description: Roman Protasevich, who organized protests against the authoritarian leader of Belarus, was arrested after the authorities forced a commercial flight to land in the capital.
content: The Belarusian opposition activist who was arrested in 2021 after the government of Belarus forced his commercial flight that was transiting its airspace to land has been sentenced to eight years in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Man Accused of Killing 5 in Texas Had Help Evading Capture, Officials Say
description: The man, Francisco Oropesa, was caught a few miles from the site of the shooting, hiding under a pile of laundry, the county sheriff said.
content: HOUSTON — Officials said on Wednesday that they had arrested the wife of the man they believe had fatally shot five people in a neighborhood dispute outside Cleveland, Texas. The arrest was one of several the authorities made after locating and arresting the suspect on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: How Messi’s Marriage With P.S.G. Fell Apart
description: A missed practice, a Saudi vacation and a brief suspension brought a sudden end to a star’s transactional relationship with Paris St.-Germain, and Qatar.
content: The moment the private jet carrying Lionel Messi to a lucrative sponsorship engagement in Saudi Arabia taxied onto a French runway early this week, his career at Paris St.-Germain was effectively over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: What to See on Europe’s Opera Stages Next Season
description: Among our critic’s recommendations are multiple “Ring” cycles, a premiere by Ellen Reid and the soprano Lise Davidsen in Strauss’s “Salome.”
content: Keeping up with opera in Europe is a nearly impossible task. There never seems to be enough time, or money, to see all that the continent has to offer across its many storied houses. Many of the most important among them have announced their 2023-24 seasons. Here are some highlights, in chronological order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong, Michael Crowley and Declan Walsh
title: How U.S. Efforts to Guide Sudan to Democracy Ended in War
description: Critics say the Biden administration and its partners were naïve about the intentions of two rival generals and failed to empower civilian leaders.
content: Just weeks ago, American diplomats thought Sudan was on the verge of a breakthrough agreement that would advance its transition from military dictatorship to full-fledged democracy, delivering on the soaring promise of the country’s revolution in 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: Judge Dismisses Trump’s Lawsuit Against The New York Times
description: Former President Donald J. Trump, who had sued The Times, three of its reporters and his niece over an investigation into his tax returns, was ordered to pay The Times’s legal expenses.
content: A New York judge dismissed former President Donald J. Trump’s lawsuit against The New York Times on Wednesday, saying the newspaper’s Pulitzer Prize-winning investigation into his finances was clearly protected by the First Amendment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Chen
title: Judge Allows Abortion Clinics to Remain Open in Utah for Now
description: The judge temporarily blocked a new law would have required the procedure be performed in hospitals, and effectively restricted access across the state, clinic operators say.
content: A Utah state judge on Tuesday temporarily blocked a new law, one day before it was scheduled to take effect, that would have banned abortion clinics and potentially put a halt to most abortions in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lina M. Khan
title: Lina Khan: We Must Regulate A.I. Here’s How.
description: Lina Khan, chair of the Federal Trade Commission, on the agency’s oversight of the A.I. revolution.
content: It’s both exciting and unsettling to have a realistic conversation with a computer. Thanks to the rapid advance of generative artificial intelligence, many of us have now experienced this potentially revolutionary technology with vast implications for how people live, work and communicate around the world. The full extent of generative A.I.’s potential is still up for debate, but there’s little doubt it will be highly disruptive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becky Ferreira
title: It’s the End of a World as We Know It
description: Astronomers spotted a dying star swallowing a large planet, a discovery that fills in a “missing link” in understanding the fates of Earth and many other planets.
content: Astronomers have witnessed a star gobbling up a planet, offering the first direct glimpse of a gnarly process called planetary engulfment that most likely awaits Earth in the deep future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Howard University Selects a New President, a Historian
description: Ben Vinson III, the provost of Case Western Reserve, will lead an institution that has surged, with record research grants and high-profile academic hires.
content: Howard University, the renowned historically Black institution that was founded to educate freed slaves, has selected a historian of Latin America as its next president, as the university’s leaders hope to continue its trajectory of surging enrollment and research growth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: An Internet Reporter Invites You to Her Group Chat
description: Madison Malone Kircher, who covers online culture, recently started a newsletter that digs into the occasionally viral, sometimes strange and often heartwarming trends that take over the internet.
content: As an internet reporter for the Styles desk at The New York Times, Madison Malone Kircher has covered a viral T-shirt paid for in blood, A.I.-generated selfies and a marketing professor who told his students their final exam would be canceled — if they went viral on TikTok. And that’s just in the past few months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman and Alan Feuer
title: Former F.B.I. Agent Charged in Jan. 6 Riot
description: Prosecutors say the former agent, who worked counterterrorism in the New York field office before leaving the bureau in 2017, called police officers Nazis and illegally entered the Capitol.
content: WASHINGTON — Federal prosecutors have charged a former F.B.I. agent with illegally entering the Capitol during the Jan. 6 riot and said he had called police officers Nazis as he encouraged a mob of Trump loyalists to kill them.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: For King Charles’s Coronation, a Fancy Fish Pie Without the Fish
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, May 3, 2023.
content: “It would be inappropriate in these times to present lampreys to anybody.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Subway Rider Choked Homeless Man to Death, Medical Examiner Rules
description: Jordan Neely died after a man held him in a chokehold. On Wednesday, the medical examiner’s office said the cause of death was compression of the neck, and ruled it a homicide.
content: The death of a New York City subway rider who was placed in a chokehold by another passenger on Monday was ruled a homicide, the city’s medical examiner confirmed on Wednesday evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Jim Marchant, a Nevada Election Denier, Announces Senate Run
description: Mr. Marchant, who lost his bid for Nevada’s secretary of state last year, will now attempt to unseat Senator Jacky Rosen, the Democratic incumbent.
content: Jim Marchant, a vocal election denier and Trump ally who lost his bid for Nevada’s secretary of state in last year’s midterm elections, declared his candidacy on Tuesday for the Senate in a swing state contest that could decide control of the chamber in 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: No Criminal Charges for Former Officer Who Fired Taser at Tyre Nichols
description: Preston Hemphill, who fired a Taser at Mr. Nichols but did not participate in the brutal beating that led to his death, has repeatedly met with prosecutors in recent weeks.
content: A former Memphis police officer who fired a Taser at Tyre Nichols, the Black FedEx worker who was brutally beaten by several other officers in January after a traffic stop, will not be criminally charged in connection with Mr. Nichols’s death days after the beating, a top prosecutor said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: How to Automatically Edit and Enhance Your Smartphone Photos
description: Photo apps have been using artificial intelligence for years to give you control over the look of your images. Here’s how to take advantage of that.
content: In today’s world of socially shared images, the urge to post a “perfect” photo, free of distractions and blemishes, is nothing new — the practice of manipulating photographs can be traced back to the 19th century. But instead of using laborious darkroom techniques and other manual methods, artificial intelligence and machine learning built into sophisticated smartphone apps now makes it easy for anyone to significantly alter a digital picture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Why Americans Feel More Pain
description: Chronic pain is not just a result of car accidents and workplace injuries but is also linked to troubled childhoods, loneliness, job insecurity and a hundred other pressures on working families.
content: Ever since Bobbie Wert was 8 years old, her stomach has hurt. “My tummy hurts,” was her refrain as a girl, and the ache was accompanied by vomiting and diarrhea that kept her out of school — sometimes for half the days in the school year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Bensinger
title: In Blow to DeSantis, Florida Bills to Limit Press Protections Are Shelved
description: Gov. Ron DeSantis usually gets what he wants from the State Legislature. But on high-profile defamation bills it was right-wing news media, not the Republican governor, that flexed its muscle.
content: Legislation that would have sharply curbed press protections in Florida has stalled in the State Legislature and won’t face a vote this year — a rare example of forces on the right thwarting a piece of Gov. Ron DeSantis’s agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Serbia School Attack Is a Rare Mass Shooting Outside the U.S.
description: The attack in Belgrade, which killed eight people, was the first mass shooting in the country in recent years.
content: A mass shooting on Wednesday, in which eight students and a security guard were killed at a school in Serbia’s capital, Belgrade, was a reminder that such attacks are far less common outside the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $625,000 Homes in Minnesota, Rhode Island and Kentucky
description: A four-bedroom bungalow in Minneapolis, a one-bedroom condominium in an 1877 mansion in Newport and a brick townhouse in Louisville.
content: During a 2022 renovation, this house was updated with new appliances, a new HVAC system, a family room and a wood deck, and the basement was finished. The property is in Fulton, a bustling neighborhood with shops and restaurants along nearby 50th Street. Edina Mann Theatre, a movie theater specializing in independent and foreign films, is half a mile away, in the popular 50th and France commercial corridor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Why New York’s Giant Trash Bag Piles May Be an Endangered Species
description: Containerization, which has been embraced by global cities like Barcelona and Buenos Aires, could force New York to eliminate 150,000 parking spots.
content: New York City, where sidewalks have long been overrun by foul-smelling heaps of garbage bags that force passers-by to yield to oncoming rat traffic, is about to try a not-so-novel idea to solve the problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: What Fed Rate Increases Mean for Mortgages, Credit Cards and More
description: Savers will benefit and borrowers can expect to pay more on credit cards, student loans and other forms of debt.
content: As the Federal Reserve has steadily lifted its key interest rate over the past year, Americans have seen the effects on both sides of the household ledger: Savers benefit from higher yields, but borrowers pay more.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What Is Coronation Chicken?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hanna Ingber and Leo Dominguez
title: The Digital Fragments We Leave Behind After Death
description: The photos, texts, playlists and to-do lists that we find after loved ones die can offer poignant glimpses into their lives.
content: The photos, texts, playlists and to-do lists that we find after loved ones die can offer poignant glimpses into their lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeenah Moon, Mark Abramson and Philip Cheung
title: What We Saw on Day 1 of the Writers’ Strike
description: Hundreds of writers picketed in New York and Los Angeles on Tuesday.
content: Hundreds of writers picketed in New York and Los Angeles on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Hayden Panettiere Is Back Onscreen
source.name: The New York Times

title: Yellowstone National Park’s Obsidian Cliff
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Examined Life of Melanie Lynskey
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: Student Kills 8 Children and a Security Guard at a School in Serbia
description: A seventh-grade student killed nine people at his school in Belgrade, the capital of Serbia.
content: A seventh-grade student killed nine people at his school in Belgrade, the capital of Serbia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times and The Associated Press
title: Federal Reserve Raises Interest Rates by Another Quarter Point
description: During a news conference, Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, opened the door to possibly pausing future rate hikes.
content: During a news conference, Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, opened the door to possibly pausing future rate hikes.
source.name: The New York Times
